reviewText:
This game pretty good if people play.  The game is simple setup where you have x-ray vision for few seconds or just shoot people in face.  Can also use emp style grenades to confuse enemy with x-ray.  No female characters so x-ray vision has limited use.

Like I say this is a good game if people play.  However, people not play.  Server always dead really so you are spending all evening watching lobby.  Sometimes I use pen to write pretend names on my screen but computer too clever.  Game do not start unless real people join.

You can play coop mode with friends or more likely alone.  This is not bad for a while but you only have limited number of maps, and enemies always same.  After a while you find X Factor interesting.  When X Factor interesting you need new hobby.

reviewText: Blacklight Tango Down is the first in the series of Blacklight games; currently there are two, and this is the prequel to Blacklight Retribution.\n\nIn terms of gameplay, this game is amazing despite multiplayer being dead. For $1 Black Ops; the semi-campaign mode of this game is quite worth it. The AI seems to actually be better than the AI in Blacklight Retribution's Onslaught mode and while it lacks the content of Blacklight Retribution, it is still quite a classic game. Only downside is G4WL, but other than that it's still a playable gem.

reviewText: Blacklight: Tango Down is an interesting futuristic shooter that has an emphasis on what technology does for an individual soldier. Rather than looking through the world with your eyes, you're seeing it through a screen painted on your helmet which can receive all sorts of disruption such as EMP grenades that require your helmet to reboot and digital" smoke grenades that disrupt rendering in that direction.\n\nWhile in reality it's a really basic shooter
date: the premise is enough to make me recommend it based on that alone. Combine that with an exhaustive array of customizations for your equipment (and not only just stats
recommended: but visually) and there's plenty to play around with. The only real problem with this game is the lack of a reliable community and matchmaking system."

reviewText:
Almost everyone who buys this game gets a bad CD Key that has already been hacked by someone else and registered here on steam. This INCLUDES buying it directly from the steam store. I bought my copy here on steam and got a bad key, when I contacted support they told me to contact the people I bought it from and get a refund.

Add funds to your steam wallet and then buy the game, then get a refund for the steam wallet via your bank, and not the ammount for the game. So if you add 50.00 to your Steam wallet, and you buy the game, get a bad key like me. You can contact your bank, have them issue a refund for a faulty product (50.00 you added to steam) when really the game was only 2.50. See the profit here?

I have posted this to say Screw steam and their â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ support, after waiting a week I was told to talk to the people who I bought the game from and get a refund. THATS YOU STEAM!

reviewText: It's a shame that GFWL is being put to rest because this game and Halo 2 were the big powerhouses of GFWL. Blacklight Retribution is a fun and expansive F2P game but this was a great kickstart to the series. Very minimal First-Person gunplay combined with a small but unique story while all being focused on a convincingly real futuristic world of electronic warfare. If you have $5 to waste; Instead of going to spend it on a meal at McDonald's, spend it on this here game. Even though you won't be able to play much (if any) online games, I promise the single-player missions will be all the fun you're looking for in a small game like this. The missions are short, but they have a decent replay value and I find myself running through them every few months just for nostalgia purposes.\n\nIn short, if you're looking for a neat little sci-fi shoot'em-up, you've found one for quite a good price.

reviewText:
I completly enjoy this game and reccomend it to anyone that likes futuristic shooters.

It has great gamemodes similar to Call Of Duty, Battlefield, etc.

It's a shame that no one is on Multiplayer anymore, because it is a masterpiece, but no one notices it, it runs well on most system and requires DirectX9, not like Retribution where you need DirectX11.

This isn't a Pay2Win game like Retribution, you earn things and keep them by leveling up. Not by constantly paying for Zen. You don't keep things you earn unless you buy them with Credits in-game, or real money. There is no currency or anything in Tango Down. And it's easier to level up than pay real money for guns and things in Retribution.

There is more things in Retribution to try, but I do wish it focuses more on the F2P" method
date: Tango Down's only $0.99 on the Store
recommended: so it's fine for your wallet. The core gameplay of Tango Down is more fun than the gadgets in Retribution.\n\nThe servers in Tango Down are always up and running. Not like Retribution
hoursPlayed: you need to connect to Europe to play on public servers
voteText: and even private servers.\n\nI think this game deserves more attention than Retribution

The storyline sucks; sometimes it makes me wonder if there is even a story at all, very amateurishly written. Gun modifications are impressive but thatâ€™s pretty much the only impressive thing in this game. Donâ€™t even get me started on multiplayer; itâ€™s full of fail with no dedicated server and only match-making crap. Oh yeah did I mention the multiplayer community is dead? Well its dead so save yourself some money and donâ€™t buy this sorry excuse of a game.

reviewText:
The game may be dead (online), but if you could find people to coordinate playtimes with - or have friends who play actually - then this game is a blast!

This game would be a 'one-hit-wonder' if it was in the music industry. All I heard was people raving about how awesome it was when it was released. Sadly, I'm cheap and wouldn't buy the game at full price. I now regret that since I can't really experience the game fully whenever I want. I'm assuming the game basically lost player base due to the lack of new maps....which does make it a bit boring after awhile. However, (like I first stated) if you have friends who play it, or can coordinate with others, then the game is pretty fun.

I do recommend the game. It is a blast - better with friends/partners - and provides some cool customizations. Of course, now BL:Retribution is out...and free...which also draws people away from this game. So, along with recommending the game, I will also recommend to not buy the game at full price unless you have 4+ friends/partners to play with when you want to....

reviewText: The game is good and even though the multiplayer is 'dead' it is only because nobody wants to make an effort to play. The multiplayer is like on cod black ops, users host the game at random. But even without the multiplayer it is still fun. Just play the black ops mode.

Although the game is tempting, it is targeted for multiplayer. The multiplayer sucks only because it is so incredibly hard to get a game started at all. I have attempted to join games, but there are no games ready to join ever. It forces me to start a game lobby to wait for others interested in joining. You have to wait till somewhere between 6 and 10 people are ready to play the game with you, or you can not start the game/match. No one can join midgame. I have waited 30 minutes on several occasions for more than 5 people to join, and by then everyone leaves. Because of this I hate the game.

The single player seems fun. Although the AI will stomp you if you rush in, if you are cautious the AI is incredibly easy. After getting to character level 2 I stopped playing, having 80 kills and 3 deaths. Too easy. (3 deaths from rushing in during the first scene. When i started to play cautious I did not die once, it became unchallenging.)

It's sad to see a game with so much potential get shut down so quickly. Out the gate Blacklight:Tango Down was plagued with poor support and game ruining glitches. This isn't a bad thing and it serves its purpose but I really wanted this version of the game to succeed.

I love this game. Multi-player isn't worth touching (as with almost any MP game), but the single-player/co-op mode is so fun! The AI is awful, the weapons are cool, and it's somehow addictive. I used to play this all the time on the Xbox 360! Best part is, you can, like in Rainbow 6: Vegas 2, gain Xp from solo or co-op so you aren't destroyed by the multi-player no-lifers and/or cheaters. Most multi-player games are meant for the veteran players to have OP weapons so that newbies are just cannon fodder. This game prevents such lobsided matches. You can enter your 1st PvP match fully decked out, like all multi-player games should be. Good job, Zombie Studios!

reviewText: The game is fun (More fun than it's sequel in my opinion), but few people play anymore.  I bought in for the sole purpose of having a fun FPS to play with my friend, and it works amazingly well for that.  Also, my play time is not accurate, I had this game on Xbox long before I started playing it here.
This game was overhyped with hardly any patches. I will never play this game again!
Excellent game. Challenging and entertaining.

Considering this game is a buck, I don't think you won't be disappointed, but something to keep in mind is that this is a GFWL (Games for Windows Live) game, and if you have Windows 8, you may not be able to run this. With all that stated, let's review this game.

StoryBlabbity Blah FPS games have no story, this game is no exception. There's not really so much a story as much as it was a tacked on description of the two factions -- The Blacklight Team and the Order -- which I will be copying word for word directly from the game for notes. The TL;DR of it is that it's the best of the best soldiers using the best (American, obviously) equipment to look for their Colonel while The Order is slowly coming in for the kill.

Who is Blacklight?
Blacklight is the covert ops unit that places the most advanced U.S. military technology in the hands of the finest soldiers in the world. Hyper Reality Visors, reactive armor and digital grenades are just a few of the cutting edge weapons that make these next-gen warriors the elite fighting force in the world. The team has been brought in to investigate the disappearance of one of their own; Colonel Klein and his team of Blacklight operatives. On the ground, the Blacklight team has found that things have quickly deteriorated and their search for Klien has evolved into their battle against The Order.

Who is The Order?
The Order is a highly organized rebel group composed of Ex-US special forces and local militia, who have joined the cause. As former members of various militaries, these rogue soldiers use their top level training to build daunting fortifications that shield the construction of an advanced infrastructure that supplements further development of their own impresive cache of military hardware and new technology. Their equipment is the best hardware and technology that money can buy, purchased using their military contacts throughout the world.

Graphics / AestheticsGraphics do support up to 1080p, but there are pretty much only two options out of the entire list, and that would be shader details (Which are on a number-based option, from 1-5), and the resolution. I guess you could include brightness, but bare with me on what I'm about to say. The aesthetics in this game are obstensibly giving a bleak apocalyptic setting, and your Hyper Reality Visor pretty much takes you out of the vision that you might be playing a liquidated fallout game

GameplayAside from what you can expect from most FPS games these days, offering TDM, DM, S&D, CTF, and other strange variations, there's not much you can expect out of this game either. That's not to say this game was lackluster, but the main gimmick was that there was HRV, but it didn't hold out much hope when the majority of the maps were relatively small. When you aimed down sights, the weapon model would move directly to the middle of the screen. I guess one could say it was to make it simialr to doom, but I don't see the reference.

Blacklight Retribution certainly had some changes that were for the better though. The addition of the tactical gear may not seem innovative, but compared to how it was in Tango Down, it actually seems laughable; These healing and ammunation stations that players would have, it almost seems as if it were abusable, and I wouldn't be surprised if it was. Customization remains to be a feature, that along with the story, needed an explanation for in a different tab.

It was neat to have, but much like how I've been building this review, came with some setbacks. The level requirement for each one was set at an ungodly curve, requiring you to play a LOt to get the Doritos Pro MLG Swagging gear"

While a superior title to it's horribly unbalanced, free-to-lose-repeatedly-until-you-pay sequel, Blacklight: Tango Down was a largely forgettable experience, in spite of its good presentation and customization. The interesting element of a built-in wallhack as a gameplay feature makes it stick in my mind, but it had speedhackers on day one and its crippingly small playerbase dried up weeks later. This game is a testament to why making multiplayer-only games is still a bad idea, as is using the console version of a multiplatform title as your baseline.
